newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Force with News Corp only briefly-analysts.
newsitem.headline: Force with News Corp only briefly-analysts.

text.p: The force may have been with News Corp so far this year but more earthly dangers await Rupert Murdoch's global media empire, analysts said on Thursday.

News Corp announced on Thursday a 34 percent rise in net profit before abnormals to A$376 million (US$293 million) in the three months to March 31, driven largely by Fox Television and Fox Film's re-release of the Star Wars movie trilogy.
Net profits after abnormals were A$330 million, up from A$77 million in the same period last year.
British newspapers and BkyB also produced significant profit contributions, while News' book publishing amd Australasian newspaper and pay television were the main drags on profit, News said.
But the results received a lukewarm reception from the market. News' shares ended at A$6.01, off five cents on the day.
"Overall, it's not all good news for News," said one Melbourne analyst.

Murdoch last year predicted that News could achieve a 20 percent profit rise for the year to June 30, 1997, a forecast not borne out by first-half results. Net profit before abnormals for the first nine months was 17 percent up at A$1.11 billion.
A Sydney-based analyst estimated News would report a net profit of A$1.64 billion before abnormals for the full year.
"They are probably going to achieve (the 20 percent profit growth)," the analyst said.
Other analysts said the third quarter profit was not enough to make them change their forecasts.
"Overall, the result is at the higher end of market expectations but it's not enough to get people excited," a Melbourne-based analyst said.

Filmed Entertainment revenues rose sharply to A$1.138 billion from A$584 million, although its operating income had a more modest rise from A$82 million from A$63 million in the same period a year earlier.
Analysts, however, say the film arm will return to earth in the last quarter and early in the next financial year because of two big-budget disaster movies -- "Volcano" and "Titanic".
"Volcano", about an eruption in Los Angeles, reportedly cost about US$100 million to make but had a cumulative gross of US$27 million to May 5.
The release of "Titanic", reputedly the most expensive movie ever made, has been pushed back past the traditional U.S. opening date of July 4.
"Titanic won't affect them this year but Volcano will be a loss-maker," a Melbourne analyst said.
"There's no way film will be the same next year."
Analysts said investors were still wary of investing in News Corp until it sorts out its U.S. satellite TV business American Sky Broadcasting (ASkyB).
Uncertainty surrounds News Corp's ASkyB plans following its tie-up with Echostar Communications Corp. The venture has run into several problems since the deal was announced in February.
"The prevailing issue remains ASkyB and until that issue is resolved satisfactorily it is going to remain a big problem for them," a Sydney analyst said.
